what: Computing Log-Transformed Kernel Density Estimates for Positive Data
title: Computing Log-Transformed Kernel Density Estimates for Positive Data
text: goal logKDE provide set functions kernel density estimation positive domain, using log-kernel density functions, R programming environment. main functions package logdensity logdensity_fft functions. choice functional syntax made resemble density function, conducting kernel density estimation real domain. logdensity function conducts density estimation, via first principle computations, whereas logdensity_fft utilizes fast-Fourier transformation order speed computation. use Rcpp guarantees methods sufficiently fast large data scenarios. Currently, variety kernel functions plugin bandwidth methods available. default logdensity logdensity_fft set use log-normal kernel functions (kernel = 'gaussian') Silverman’s rule--thumb bandwidth, applied log-transformed data (bw = 'nrd0'). However, following kernels also available: log-Epanechnikov (kernel = 'epanechnikov'), log-Laplace (kernel = 'laplace'), log-logistic (kernel = 'logistic'), log-triangular (kernel = 'triangular'), log-uniform (kernel = 'uniform'). following plugin bandwidth methods also available: methods available density, applied log-transformed data (see ?bw.nrd regarding options), unbiased cross-validated bandwidths positive domain (bw = 'logcv'), Silverman-type rule--thumb optimizes kernel density estimator fit, compared log-normal density function (bw = 'logg'). logdensity logdensity_fft functions also behave way density, called within plot function. usual assortment commands apply plot output objects can also called. comprehensive review literature positive-domain kernel density estimation, thorough descriptions mathematics relating methods described, simulation results, example applications logKDE package, please consult package vignette. vignette available via command vignette('logKDE'), package installed.

title: Computing Log-Transformed Kernel Density Estimates for Positive Data
text: example, demonstrate logdensity nearly identical syntax density. also show format outputs also nearly identical.   note, one can observe density assigns positive probability negative values. Since know chi-squared generative model generates positive values, undesirable result. log-transformed kernel density estimator produced logdensity assigns positive probability positive values, thus bona fide estimation scenario.
code: ## Load 'logKDE' library. library(logKDE)  ## Set a random seed. set.seed(1)  ## Generate strictly positive data. ## Data are generated from a chi-squared distribution with 12 degrees of freedom. x <- rchisq(100,6)  ## Construct and print the output of the function 'density'. density(x) #>  #> Call: #>  density.default(x = x) #>  #> Data: x (100 obs.);  Bandwidth 'bw' = 1.018 #>  #>        x                y             #>  Min.   :-2.366   Min.   :4.707e-05   #>  1st Qu.: 2.547   1st Qu.:7.209e-03   #>  Median : 7.459   Median :3.315e-02   #>  Mean   : 7.459   Mean   :5.079e-02   #>  3rd Qu.:12.372   3rd Qu.:1.012e-01   #>  Max.   :17.284   Max.   :1.311e-01  ## Construct and print the output of the function 'logdensity'. logdensity(x) #>  #> Call: #>  logdensity(x = x) #>  #> Data: x (100 obs.);  Bandwidth 'bw' = 0.1923 #>  #>        x                 y           #>  Min.   : 0.1111   Min.   :0.00000   #>  1st Qu.: 3.7851   1st Qu.:0.02313   #>  Median : 7.4592   Median :0.06527   #>  Mean   : 7.4592   Mean   :0.06707   #>  3rd Qu.:11.1333   3rd Qu.:0.11219   #>  Max.   :14.8073   Max.   :0.13698  ## Plot the 'density' output object. plot(density(x)) ## Plot the 'logdensity' output object. plot(logdensity(x))

title: Computing Log-Transformed Kernel Density Estimates for Positive Data
text: example, showcase variety kernel functions available package. , log-transformed kernel density estimators constructed using logdensity function.
code: ## Load 'logKDE' library. library(logKDE)  ## Set a random seed. set.seed(1)  ## Generate strictly positive data. ## Data are generated from a chi-squared distribution with 12 degrees of freedom. x <- rchisq(100,12)  ## Construct a log-KDE using the data, and using each of the available kernel functions. logKDE1 <- logdensity(x,kernel = 'gaussian',from = 1e-6,to = 30) logKDE2 <- logdensity(x,kernel = 'epanechnikov',from = 1e-6,to = 30) logKDE3 <- logdensity(x,kernel = 'laplace',from = 1e-6,to = 30) logKDE4 <- logdensity(x,kernel = 'logistic',from = 1e-6,to = 30) logKDE5 <- logdensity(x,kernel = 'triangular',from = 1e-6,to = 30) logKDE6 <- logdensity(x,kernel = 'uniform',from = 1e-6,to = 30)  ## Plot the true probability density function of the generative model. plot(c(0,30),c(0,0.1),type='n',xlab='x',ylab='Density',main='Example 2') curve(dchisq(x,12),from = 0,to = 30,add = T)  ## Plot each of the log-KDE functions, each in a different rainbow() colour. lines(logKDE1$x,logKDE1$y,col = rainbow(7)[1]) lines(logKDE2$x,logKDE2$y,col = rainbow(7)[2]) lines(logKDE3$x,logKDE3$y,col = rainbow(7)[3]) lines(logKDE4$x,logKDE4$y,col = rainbow(7)[4]) lines(logKDE5$x,logKDE5$y,col = rainbow(7)[5]) lines(logKDE6$x,logKDE6$y,col = rainbow(7)[6])  ## Add a grid for a visual guide. grid()

title: Computing Log-Transformed Kernel Density Estimates for Positive Data
text: example, show logdensity logdensity_ftt yield nearly identical results. , log-transformed kernel density estimators constructed using logdensity_ftt function.  observe logdensity_fft outputs noticiably smoother logdensity. fast Fourier transformations (FFT) yield kernel density estimates discrete points, regions discrete points approximated via linear approximator, namely using approx function. evaluation technique used function density. Additionally FFT approximation points evenly space real line, whereas used logdensity evenly spaced log scale.
code: ## Load 'logKDE' library. library(logKDE)  ## Set a random seed. set.seed(1)  ## Generate strictly positive data. ## Data are generated from a chi-squared distribution with 12 degrees of freedom. x <- rchisq(100,12)  ## Construct a log-KDE using the data, and using each of the available kernel functions. logKDE1 <- logdensity_fft(x,kernel = 'gaussian',from = 1e-6,to = 30) logKDE2 <- logdensity_fft(x,kernel = 'epanechnikov',from = 1e-6,to = 30) logKDE3 <- logdensity_fft(x,kernel = 'laplace',from = 1e-6,to = 30) logKDE4 <- logdensity_fft(x,kernel = 'logistic',from = 1e-6,to = 30) logKDE5 <- logdensity_fft(x,kernel = 'triangular',from = 1e-6,to = 30) logKDE6 <- logdensity_fft(x,kernel = 'uniform',from = 1e-6,to = 30)  ## Plot the true probability density function of the generative model. plot(c(0,30),c(0,0.1),type='n',xlab='x',ylab='Density',main='Example 3') curve(dchisq(x,12),from = 0,to = 30,add = T)  ## Plot each of the log-KDE functions, each in a different rainbow() colour. lines(logKDE1$x,logKDE1$y,col = rainbow(7)[1]) lines(logKDE2$x,logKDE2$y,col = rainbow(7)[2]) lines(logKDE3$x,logKDE3$y,col = rainbow(7)[3]) lines(logKDE4$x,logKDE4$y,col = rainbow(7)[4]) lines(logKDE5$x,logKDE5$y,col = rainbow(7)[5]) lines(logKDE6$x,logKDE6$y,col = rainbow(7)[6])  ## Add a grid for a visual guide. grid()

title: Computing Log-Transformed Kernel Density Estimates for Positive Data
text: example, showcase variety plugin bandwidth estimators available package. , log-transformed kernel density estimators constructed using logdensity function.
code: ## Load 'logKDE' library. library(logKDE)  ## Set a random seed. set.seed(1)  ## Generate strictly positive data. ## Data are generated from a chi-squared distribution with 12 degrees of freedom. x <- rchisq(100,12)  ## Construct a log-KDE using the data, and using each of the available kernel functions. logKDE1 <- logdensity(x,bw = 'nrd0',from = 1e-6,to = 30) logKDE2 <- logdensity(x,bw = 'logcv',from = 1e-6,to = 30) logKDE3 <- logdensity(x,bw = 'logg',from = 1e-6,to = 30) logKDE4 <- logdensity(x,bw = 'nrd',from = 1e-6,to = 30) logKDE5 <- logdensity(x,bw = 'ucv',from = 1e-6,to = 30) #> Warning in stats::bw.ucv(log(x)): minimum occurred at one end of the range logKDE6 <- logdensity(x,bw = 'bcv',from = 1e-6,to = 30) #> Warning in stats::bw.bcv(log(x)): minimum occurred at one end of the range logKDE7 <- logdensity(x,bw = 'SJ-ste',from = 1e-6,to = 30) logKDE8 <- logdensity(x,bw = 'SJ-dpi',from = 1e-6,to = 30)   ## Plot the true probability density function of the generative model. plot(c(0,30),c(0,0.1),type='n',xlab='x',ylab='Density',main='Example 4') curve(dchisq(x,12),from = 0,to = 30,add = T)  ## Plot each of the log-KDE functions with different choices of bandwidth, each in a different rainbow() colour. lines(logKDE1$x,logKDE1$y,col = rainbow(9)[1]) lines(logKDE2$x,logKDE2$y,col = rainbow(9)[2]) lines(logKDE3$x,logKDE3$y,col = rainbow(9)[3]) lines(logKDE4$x,logKDE4$y,col = rainbow(9)[4]) lines(logKDE5$x,logKDE5$y,col = rainbow(9)[5]) lines(logKDE6$x,logKDE6$y,col = rainbow(9)[6]) lines(logKDE7$x,logKDE7$y,col = rainbow(9)[7]) lines(logKDE8$x,logKDE8$y,col = rainbow(9)[8])  ## Add a grid for a visual guide. grid()

title: Summary
text: Exploratory data analysis, proposed @tukey1977exploratory, important paradigm conducting meaningful useful applied statistics. According Chapters 5, 19, 20 @tukey1977exploratory, visualization data, density distributional characteristics, may provide practitioners great insight necessary processes required order effectively analyse various features data. Since introduction pioneering works @rosenblatt1956remarks @parzen1962estimation, method kernel density estimation (KDE) become among one popular methods estimation, interpolation, visualization probability density functions (PDFs), due effectiveness simplicity. manuscripts @silverman2018density @wand1994kernel provide thorough treatments topic KDE. base stats package R programming environment [@R2016], univariate KDE can conducted via function, density. function, density, often taught introductory R classes presented popular textbooks. See example Section 5.6 @venables1228bd, Section 7.4 @trosset2009introduction, Section 6.3 @keen2010graphics, Section 2.1 @maindonald2010data, Section 2.3 @verzani2014using. KDE method implemented density standard KDE technique estimation univariate PDFs, assuming data real-valued. Unfortunately, density often used analyze data real-valued, income data, positive-valued [cf, @charpentier2015log]. use density case positive-valued data causes obtained estimator PDF characterizes data integrate one, positive domain. implies provide incorrect specification data generating process. order mitigate aforementioned shortcoming density, @charpentier2015log, among others, suggested use kernel density estimators (KDEs), constructed log-normal kernel functions. log-transformed KDEs, log-KDEs brevity, bona fide PDFs positive domain, thus suited applications positive-valued data. logKDE package R provides functions conducting log-transformed KDE using log-KDEs, constructed log-normal, well log-transformations Epanechnikov, Laplace, logistic, triangular, uniform families kernel functions, main function, logdensity. function allows variety bandwidth methods, including Silverman’s rule thumb [cf. @silverman2018density], cross-validation natural log-transformation space, new rule thumb based comparison log-KDE log-normal fit. necessary, programmed various functionalities C++, integrated C++ codes using Rcpp [@eddelbuettel2013seamless]. greater speed, expense accuracy, also implemented fast Fourier transform version procedure, via function, logdensity_fft. two packages currently available, share similar features logKDE. first Ake [@RJ2016045], via ker = 'LN' setting dke.fun, second evmix [@hu2018evmix], via dbckden, setting bcmethod = 'logtrans'. Unlike logKDE, Ake offers log-transformed KDE constructed log-normal kernels. Although evmix allows construction log-KDEs using variety kernels, including currently available logKDE, permit use log-Laplace log-logistic kernels. Thus, respect variety kernels, packages something offer . believe key difference evmix logKDE user experience. logKDE, logdensity designed closely replicate syntax behavior density. Thus, users learnt use density quickly make use logdensity features. syntax dbckden dramatically different density. function allows many controls meant higher level users may overwhelm someone interested conducting KDE exploratory tool. Therefore, believe logdensity provides experience user friendly familiar dbckden. Users can obtain latest build logKDE GitHub (https://github.com/andrewthomasjones/logKDE). latest stable build can obtained CRAN (https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=logKDE), archival build can obtained Zenodo (https://zenodo.org/record/1339352). detailed literature review, mathematical study, simulation study, demonstration log-transformed KDE method appear vignette package, can accessed via command vignette('logKDE'). Thorough descriptions package functions appear manual, can accessed https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/logKDE/logKDE.pdf. Bug reports feedback can directed GitHub issues page (https://github.com/andrewthomasjones/logKDE/issues).

title: Kernel Density Estimates of strictly positive distributions. — logdensity
code: logdensity(   x,   bw = "nrd0",   adjust = 1,   kernel = "gaussian",   weights = NULL,   n = 512,   from,   to,   cut = 3,   na.rm = FALSE )

title: Kernel Density Estimates of strictly positive distributions. — logdensity
text: x data estimate computed. bw smoothing bandwidth used. Can also can also character string giving rule choose bandwidth. Like density defaults "nrd0". options  help(bw.nrd) available well "bw.logCV" "bw.logG". adjust bandwidth used actually adjust*bw. kernel character string giving smoothing kernel used. Choose "gaussian", "epanechnikov", "triangular", "uniform", "laplace" "logistic". Default value "gaussian". weights numeric vector non-negative observation weights length x. n number equally spaced points density estimated. Note equally spaced original domain. , left right-points grid density estimated; defaults cut * bw outside range(x). cut default, values cut bandwidths beyond extremes data na.rm logical; TRUE, missing values removed x. FALSE missing values cause error.
